acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Statistics calculation of three data (ACGIH (2001), EHC 39 (1984)) was done, and 214.5mg/kg was obtained. It is set to Category 3.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists
acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.rationale: It was set as Category 1 since all three data (ACGIH (2001), EHC 39 (1984)) were 0.05mg/L or less except the time when dust sizes is large.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: There is no acute inhalation test data for steam, and it cannot be classified. Vapor pressure is very low and a fatal dose of steam will not be generated at normal temperature.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Statistics calculation of the data (ACGIH (2001), EHC 39 (1984)) of four examinations was done, and 230.3mg/kg was obtained. It is set as Category 3.

carcinogenicity.rationale: Since paraquat has been classified into C by EPA, it becomes the outside of Category. However, about methyl sulfates of counterion, each evaluation agencies has categorized dimethyl sulfates analogue into carcinogenic. The evaluation about Paraquat = 2 methyl hydrogen sulfate has not been performed.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available.

explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: The substance was regarded as "outside the categories". Because there are negative results from dominant lethal tests in mice and in vivo bone-marrow tests (EHC 39 (1984)). No positive results have been found in in vitro tests either.

oxidizing_solids.rationale: It does not contains fluorine and chlorine. Although it contains oxygen as sulfate ester, this nonion is not considered as an oxidizer.

reproductive_toxicity.rationale: Since there is no bad effect in oral administration experiment in three generation of rat (EHC 39 (1984)),  it is considered as "out of the Category."

respiratory_sensitizer.rationale: There is no information and it cannot be classified.

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive or self-reactive properties present in the molecule.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: The stimulus of the eye was reported with humans (ACGIH (2001)) and rabbits (EHC 39 (1984)). But the rabbit had recovered in 4 days, it was set to "Category 2B."

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Since there was information that it stimulated human skin (ACGIH (2001)) and animal skin (EHC 39 (1984)), it was classified as "Category 2." In repeated exposure, skin necrosis is also seen on rats and mice. (EHC 39(1984))

skin_sensitizer.rationale: It was put  "outside of the Category" because there is a report that sensitization was not observed with guinea pigs (EHC 39 (1984)).

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: The chemical structure of the substance does not contain metals or metaloids(B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (lung, kidney, liver)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: It was classified to as Category 1 (lungs, kidney, liver), because of the harmful effects in lungs, kidney, and liver by serum chemistry (ChE, GPT) and by pathological examination (EHC 39 (1984)) in the repeated oral administration experiment for rats within the guidance value of Category 1.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: Causes damage to organs (kidney, liver, respiratory system)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Kidney, liver, and lungs were common with each recovery case of the human accident exposure (EHC 39 (1984)). Since the respiratory disorders are mentioned in examples of accidents (ACGIH (2001)), lungs were unified with this and put to "Category 1 (kidney, liver, respiratory system)."
